Update. Here's another paywalled editorial on #openaccess that the authors/editors could have easily made OA.
https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/ijd.16576

But this one is critical, not supportive. Honest Q: Is that a reason to put it behind a paywall? Wouldn't they like their objections to have more impact?

The objections restate the classic misunderstandings that all or most OA journals charge #APCs and all or most APCs are paid by authors.

Because it's an editorial, it did not have to survive peer review.

Interesting approach from the @sklearn project:

You can install via "pip install scikit-learn", but they have an old "sklearn" package on PyPI that they want to deprecate, so they released sklearn with a brownout schedule, where it will fail to install between certain times.

And the time windows for failures will increase.

Did you see a failure? Replace "sklearn" with "scikit-learn" in your dependencies.

More info: https://github.com/scikit-learn/sklearn-pypi-package #python #scikitlearn #sklearn #deprecation

Psychologists! This is the APA position on publishing manuscripts online (as far as I can tell) https://www.apa.org/pubs/journals/resources/internet-posting-guidelines

It says you can publish the manuscript, but have to mark it copyright the APA (so no CC-BY, no permission for reuse). This makes it not compliant with funder requirements (e.g. UKRI)

Does anyone know any more about the position of the APA with respect to rights retention?

title: The Value Of Owning More Books Than You’ll Ever Read

last_post.content:
Do you own far more books than you'll ever read?

<raises hand>

Here's a useful way to think about it: All those books are what Nassim Nicholas Taleb calls an "antilibrary"

They are the whitespace around your knowledge

They keep you humble -- sure, you know stuff, but behold all the things you *don't* know!

Or, as I put it ... they're a form of "intellectual orienteering"

My essay: https://clivethompson.medium.com/the-value-of-owning-more-books-than-youll-ever-read-3d60a6046994

A "friend" link if you're not a Medium subscriber: https://clivethompson.medium.com/the-value-of-owning-more-books-than-youll-ever-read-3d60a6046994?sk=d9575f6411ee9d9a756e2b59ab1e9b2e

title: Ransomware Profits Dip as Fewer Victims Pay Extortion

last_post.content:
Good news for people who hate #ransomware: gangs' profits have been falling as fewer victims pay a ransom, leading gangs large and small to embrace more desperate tactics, including shaking down victims for a ransom again and again — which makes victims further less inclined to pay. Ransomware responders say a "subtle shift" by law enforcement to offer rapid support for victims has been making a big difference in aiding/speeding/easing recovery, while also generating valuable intel for the likes of the FBI to help blunt future attacks.

last_post.content:
I don't want to see another story on AI and college teaching that doesn't address class size and massive reliance on contingent labor.

The pedagogical strategies mentioned here are good ones even without the problem of AI, but they all require more work. And most of them require concrete, enduring relationships between specific students and specific instructors.

Which is no surprise because that's always been the basis of a good education.

title: TikTok’s Secret ‘Heating’ Button Can Make Anyone Go Viral

last_post.content:
There are two stories here, which are conflated in this article about TikTok's manual content boosting.

One is of editorial control in a platform: who has it, who uses it, who abuses it, and how.

The other is how to boost creators new to platforms so that they get equal access to engagement. This is a big problem for social networks who try to solve it both manually and algorithmically and this is the first time I've seen it discussed in a mainstream news article.

https://www.forbes.com/sites/emilybaker-white/2023/01/20/tiktoks-secret-heating-button-can-make-anyone-go-viral/

title: Revealed: how US transition to electric cars threatens environmental havoc

last_post.content:
Electric vehicles are not the answer.

If Americans continue to depend on cars at the current rate, by 2050 the US alone would need triple the lithium currently produced for the entire global market, with dire consequences for water, food supplies, biodiversity, and Indigenous rights.

We need a transition away from car dependency and towards greater use of walking, biking and public transport.
